head.title: Journal of Great Bear Lake, 1805-1806. - Page #25

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #25 of 48 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: McKenzie, Alexander. Journal of Great Bear Lake, 1805-1806. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0006

div.p: a Split Rock and as they was obliged to come out for watter &ca they killed them all and got a great deal of Bar Iron[,] Large Beads &ca[.] [T]wo of the Indians of this Band had been there[.] I was very sorry that I was not informed of this while with them as I could have had further information. I supposed that this split Rock was a stone fort as they informed my Indians that those white people came there to trade on a floting Island (a Ship)[.] [I]t tis a very disagreeable thing to be without a Enterprater when trading with different Nations, but it tis very sertain that they can do their Bussiness without them. [T]he trader only has a little more Trouble formerly when from 40 to 70 packs went from this River the best Enterpraters of Arthebaska was here to make discoveries and settle posts in Beaver Countries.

[A]t 2 Of the Clock we came to a family and traded 24 Beavers and one net[.] [F]our Cannoes of the Quarlers accompanied me[.] [A]t 4 O Clock arrived at a Small River & sett 2 nets and sent 4 Indians to serch a Band of Indians that was up this Small River[.]

The Indian Returned with some fresh meet[,] 3 Blathers of Greese and a Pack of mixt Peltries which I traded[.] [T]hose being the last Quarlers I expected to se this Spring I informed them that two of them must embark with me to go to Arthebaska and that they should return in the fall[.] [T]hey Consented[.] [A] third wished to Embark likewise[.] I told him that two was sufisent[.] [W]ell then said he I have a Cannoe of my own & I will follow you[.] I made him a Small present and promised to take him with me next Spring which sattisfied him as I had not a great supply of provisions[.] Embarked at 10 O Clock[.] Encamped at 6 O Clock Oposite some smoke on the N. side of the River[.] I fired two guns in hopes if there was any Indians at the smoke they would come to the River[.] [C]ommenced on our Toro) or Pemegan) as our pounded meet & Tongue is out[.]

Embarked at 4 O Clock[.] [W]e had a light Breeze from the N[.] [P]ut on shore at 6 O Clock in the Evening[.] Eat our supper as the wind Continued[.] [A]t 9 we Embarked but it became quite Calm[.] [A]t a 11 of the Clock we Encamped I cannot say

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
